importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article was published on October 21, 2025, marking the date when Cory Doctorow's theory of 'enshittification' was introduced to a wider audience via the Planet Money newsletter, sparking public discourse on internet platform degradation.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period between 2022 and 2023 saw the widespread adoption of the term 'enshittification' in public discourse, culminating in its recognition by the American Dialect Society as Word of the Year and inclusion in Merriam-Webster’s dictionary.

keyTakeAways: The internet is undergoing a process known as 'enshittification,' where platforms like Facebook, Google, Amazon, and Uber degrade in quality over time, shifting from user-focused models to profit-driven ones.

This degradation occurs in three stages: (1) early growth with user-friendly incentives, (2) prioritization of business customers at user expense, and (3) exploitative pricing and algorithmic manipulation that harms both users and small businesses.
Key factors driving enshittification include a lack of competition, weak consumer protection regulations, and the use of network effects and high switching costs to lock in users.

Doctorow argues that platforms exploit their market power through predatory pricing, data misuse, algorithmic manipulation, and junk fees, particularly on Amazon, where sellers lose up to 51 cents per dollar earned.

Consumers face worse search results and content feeds that prioritize paid ads over user preferences, with Amazon's top results often being 29% more expensive than the best matches and located far below the top of the search page.

Amazon and Facebook have publicly disputed Doctorow’s claims, but he supports them with studies from the Institute for Local Self-Reliance and independent research, citing evidence of platform degradation over time.

Solutions proposed include stronger antitrust enforcement, abandoning the consumer welfare standard, enforcing 'right-to-exit' policies (e.g., transferring e-books from Kindle), and promoting interoperability (e.g., allowing third-party apps and ink cartridges to work across devices).
The anti-tech monopoly movement has gained momentum globally, including among conservative voices, suggesting potential policy shifts to reverse enshittification.

namedEntities.name: Cory Doctorow
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Internet activist, journalist, and author who coined the term 'enshittification' and wrote the book with that title.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Doctorow is the central intellectual force behind the theory of enshittification, offering a detailed analysis of how internet platforms degrade over time, making him critical to understanding the article's argument.

namedEntities.name: Enshittification
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A term coined by Cory Doctorow to describe the degradation of internet platforms into exploitative, user-harming systems.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This concept is the core subject of the article, explaining how platforms like Facebook, Amazon, and Uber have evolved from user-friendly environments into profit-driven, degrading systems.

namedEntities.name: Facebook (Meta)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Social media platform that Doctorow alleges has degraded from user-focused to ad-driven and data-harvesting operations.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Facebook is a primary example of enshittification, illustrating how user data is used to manipulate feeds and push ads, leading to declining user experience and content quality.

namedEntities.name: Amazon
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: E-commerce platform and retailer that Doctorow criticizes for exploiting sellers and consumers through algorithmic manipulation and junk fees.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Amazon is highlighted as a case study in enshittification, with claims of product cloning, inflated prices, and fees that reduce seller margins to 45–51 cents per dollar earned.

namedEntities.name: Uber
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Ride-sharing platform cited in Doctorow’s analysis as an example of a company that evolved from user-centric to profit-driven operations.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Uber is part of Doctorow’s broader pattern of platform degradation, illustrating how companies prioritize business revenue over user value over time.

namedEntities.name: Google
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Search engine and technology giant that Doctorow includes in his analysis of enshittification.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Google is mentioned as a platform undergoing devolution, connecting users with advertisers and contributing to the broader trend of user data exploitation.

namedEntities.name: American Dialect Society
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Organization that named 'enshittification' Word of the Year in 2023.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This recognition validates the cultural and linguistic significance of the term, showing its widespread adoption and public relevance beyond academic circles.

namedEntities.name: Merriam-Webster
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Dictionaries company that added 'enshittification' to its dictionary.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Merriam-Webster's inclusion reflects the term's acceptance into mainstream language, reinforcing its significance in public discourse and communication.

namedEntities.name: Institute for Local Self-Reliance
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Non-profit research and advocacy group cited by Doctorow to back claims about Amazon's fees and search quality.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Provides empirical support for Doctorow's claims about Amazon’s impact on seller margins and search result quality, adding credibility to the argument.

namedEntities.name: Consumer Welfare Standard
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Legal doctrine used in antitrust cases to evaluate if a company harms consumers through higher prices.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Doctorow critiques this standard as insufficient, arguing it fails to address broader harms from monopolistic platform behavior, such as data exploitation and reduced choice.

namedEntities.name: Right-to-Exit
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Policy proposal suggesting users can transfer data or content (e.g., Kindle books) to other platforms.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Proposed as a solution to enshittification, enabling users to leave platforms and forcing companies to improve service quality to retain users.

namedEntities.name: Interoperability
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Technical concept allowing different systems or products to work together seamlessly.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Doctorow proposes interoperability as a tool to break monopolistic control, citing examples like printer ink cartridges and cross-platform messaging.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The article presents a theory by internet activist and author Cory Doctorow, known as 'enshittification,' describing how major internet platforms—such as Facebook, Amazon, Uber, and Google—have degraded from user-friendly, innovative environments into exploitative, profit-driven systems. Doctorow outlines three stages of this process: initial user-focused growth, business-centric expansion at user expense, and final exploitation involving predatory pricing, algorithmic manipulation, and hidden fees. He cites data from the Institute for Local Self-Reliance to support claims that Amazon charges sellers up to 51 cents per dollar earned and distorts search results, making top results significantly more expensive. While Amazon and Facebook refute these claims, the article emphasizes that the root causes—lack of competition and weak regulation—are systemic. Doctorow proposes solutions such as stronger antitrust enforcement, abandoning the consumer welfare standard, enforcing a 'right-to-exit' policy, and promoting interoperability to reverse the trend of enshittification and restore user trust in digital platforms.
title: A theory why the internet is going down the toilet
